content: In PHP, escape the " in the initial code  eg. /".  Instead of Program pointer out of code area at (21/0),  How about "Program Terminated" for an E, and "Program Aborted at (step): Invalid Operation" for an operation not an OPCODE instead of ignoring them (unless your intention was to let us leave comments on traces).  I'm finding this very challenging.  Especially not given the initial length of n and not having any registers (except for stack indexes).  There's multiple problems inside this problem, it's kinda making me crazy.  I'll bet I'll find more challenges as I delve deeper.  I'll leave it up to others to approve.  I think I could get a sqrt function working to limit the # of divisors, but the whole hanoi tower kinda thing is throwing me without at least 1 register.  Maybe my initial confusion(s) can be rectified easily with more example code.  This fails for test1, but I didn't wanna give it away:  echo("\"EMIRP\"CCCCCE\n");

I needed to think for a moment ... not helped by the browser which screamed when I passed the 3000 turn (or 2500 i'm not really sure because I stopped to restart it each time at the end) ... 
no indication that I had exceeded the max turn number , just crash
but except this , it is interesting, I approve
See https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/44194f48498a887fb57681c63202d76bc7c6 for the discussion in the previous version.
Nice! I think there just needs to be some text describing what needs to be optimized (step count).

My browser has a tough time showing the lengthy replays too. It got a little better when I started reusing sprites for the stack animation, but it's still terrible.
Offline it works much better (taking less RAM to show a replay), no idea why it's so heavy on CodinGame.

For the string escape I'm unfortunately bound to the limited stub generator. I can escape the " for some languages, but that again will make things worse for others.
I could just change the default code to something completely different, like generating the text my using math operators to obtain the ASCII values.

There is another way than computing sqrt(n): check if i*i > n to break.
